subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Woolworths (WOW AT) expands partnership with Caltex (CTX AT) and confirms it will pursue IPO or sale of its petrol business
content:
AUSTRALIA

ASX (ASX AT)
- Co. reports June average daily number of trades rose 2%, although average daily traded value was lower 1% at AUD 4.8bln. (Newswires)

APA Group (APA AT)
- IMF Bentham (IMF AT) is said to have hired UBS to assess if it can put together a consortium to bid for APA Group. (AFR)

Caltex (CTX AT)
- Co. and Woolworths expand partnership in which Caltex sees the retail commercial arrangements will assist on helping achieve top range of AUD 120mln-150mln EBIT uplift in 5 years. (Newswires)

Charter Hall (CHC AT)
- Co. enters agreement to sell CIP for AUD 102.5mln. (Newswires)

Perseus Mining (PRU AT)
- Co. Q4 gold output rose 31% Q/Q to 83.9k ounces. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT)
- Co. expands partnership with Caltex (CTX AT) in which 125 Caltex sites are to be added to current 638 site redemption network, while Woolworths also confirms it will pursue IPO or sale of its petrol business. (Newswires)

Other News
- The federal government will provide states an additional AUD 9bln over the next 10yrs during the transition to a new GST formula. (AFR)
- Australia signed USD 1bln deal with IBM to supply computers and software across government agencies which will save an estimated USD 100mln due to discount from buying in bulk. (AFR)


 

JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT)
- Co. Q1 net rose 0.8% Y/Y to JPY 9.58bln. (Newswires)

Aeon Co. (8267 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 6.56bln vs. Prev. JPY 3.68bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Aeon Mall (8905 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 7.89bln vs. Prev. JPY 6.95bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

ANA (9202 JT)
- Co. is to cancel 113 domestic flights between July 6th-12th to conduct inspections on Rolls-Royce engines. (Newswires)

Kansai Electric (9503 JT)
- Japanese court overturned ruling which had ordered a shutdown of Co.'s Ohi reactors. (Newswires)

Ministop (9946 JT)
- Co. Q1 net loss JPY 425mln vs. Prev. loss JPY 127mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT)
- Co. June China vehicle sales rose 10.4% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Ryohin Keikaku (7453 JT)
- Co. Q1 net rose 21.7% Y/Y to JPY 9.5bln. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. business links with Huawei Technologies have come under fresh scrutiny in the US Congress with lawmakers increasingly cautious regarding Chinese companies, while a letter from the House was also said to raise concerns regarding deal between Sprint & T-Mobile. (Nikkei)

Toyota (7203 JT)
- Co. June China vehicle sales rose 10.2% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News
- BoJ board members are reportedly split regarding the side effects of ultra-loose policy with Governor Kuroda showing concern on impact to the banking sector and with others remaining steadfast. (Nikkei)


 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. invests in Australian car sharing service Car Next Door. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. could face increasing competition in the OLED market with Chinese companies seeking to boost their market share and are expected to build 10 OLED factories during the next 3 years. (Nikkei)

Chinese state owned media says depreciation of CNY is not a long-term trend

New Zealand Treasury says 11-month budget surplus is NZD 447mln higher than expected at NZD 5.23bln
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

There were initial reports that China is to implement tariffs on USD 34bln worth of US goods as of midnight Beijing time on July 6th, according to a source. However, China’s Finance Ministry later stated they will not implement tariffs before the US does. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK PM May is said to have asked Chancellor Hammond and Business Secretary Clarke to warn colleagues of the dangers in pressing for a hard Brexit at the meeting on Friday at Chequers. Elsewhere, there were also reports that ministers warned PM May not to sidestep controversial Brexit issues at the meeting amid concern focus on customs may neglect issues such as services sector and freedom of movement. (Newswires/Guardian)

UK Brexit Secretary David Davis wrote to PM May in a last ditch attempt to warn her that her Brexit plan to be presented at Chequers is unworkable. (Telegraph)

Irish PM Varadkar said a hard Brexit is unlikely but must prepare and stated that UK-wide customs plan could apply. (Newswires)

ECB Supervisory Board Member Hakkarainen said 20 out of 50 UK banks and financial companies they had discussed exploring options on keeping banking passport, have applied for a license to operate in EU in time to get approval before Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Jun) 55.1 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.0)


EU

Some ECB policymakers are said to be concerned regarding some investors’ expectations for a hike in end-2019 which it views as too late, according to sources which suggested that the door is open for possible rate move in September or October next year. (Newswires)

US ambassador to Germany told car industry bosses that US is ready to compromise regarding tariffs and that US would not impose tariffs if EU lifts tariffs on US cars, while it was also reported that BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen executives are to meet with the US ambassador today on tariffs. (Newswires)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Jun) 55.2 vs. Exp. 55.0 (Prev. 55.0). (Newswires)
EU Markit Composite Final PMI (Jun) 54.9 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.8)


COMMODITIES

US President Trump tweeted that OPEC must remember gas prices are up and they are driving prices higher, while he urged them to reduce pricing now. (Twitter)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

UK police state that the 2 recent poisonings in Amesbury involved the same substance that was used on former Russian spy Sergei Skripal in March. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

US markets were shut for Independence Day, while European equities were mixed but with auto names in the green, on reports that the EU is considering talks with the leading global auto exporters in efforts to avoid a full-blown trade war and that heads of Daimler, BMW and VW are set to meet the US ambassador to Germany on Wednesday in an effort to avoid US tariffs. Conversely, European tech names were under pressure after Micron lost a patent lawsuit in China, while US equity futures were open for a shortened holiday session, though trade was subdued with US traders away and with ES price action was stuck around the 50dma at 2725.

Thin, rangebound trade with little of note standing out. Attention is on trade headlines, with the EU said to be flirting with cutting tariffs on autos; however, with USD 34 billion of tariffs on Chinese products coming into effect on 6 July, China is expected to retaliate, likely resulting in trade concerns rising once again. FOMC minutes on Thursday and June’s labour market report on Friday may provide the next fundamental catalysts.

subject: US SERVICE IS NOW CLOSED, PLEASE SWITCH OVER TO THE ASIA CHANNEL
ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH EQUITY CLOSE: EURO STOXX 50 (+0.16%), FTSE 100 (-0.32%), DAX (-0.23%), CAC (+0.00%), IBEX (+1.04%), FTSE MIB (-0.32%), SMI (+0.37%)
MARKET WRAP 4 July 2018: Markets mixed amid trade concerns, geopolitics, and US holiday
content:
EQUITIES: Asian equities were lower overnight on a combination of lingering concerns about global trade wars, and the PBOC draining a net 80bln yuan. European equities are mixed; auto names are in the green, however, on reports that the EU is considering talks with the leading global auto exporters in efforts to avoid a full-blown trade war – heads of Daimler, BMW and VW are set to meet the US ambassador to Germany on Wednesday in an effort to avoid US tariffs, Handelsblatt reported. European tech names were under pressure after Micron lost a patent lawsuit in China. US equity futures have been open for a shortened holiday session, though trade has been expectedly subdued with US traders out for the Independence Day holiday; ES price action was capped by the 50dma at 2725, and the ~2710 level has held action above it.

TREASURIES: Thin, rangebound trade with little of note standing out. Attention is on trade headlines, with the EU said to be flirting with cutting tariffs on autos; however, with USD 34 billion of tariffs on Chinese products coming into effect on 6 July, China is expected to retaliate, likely resulting in trade concerns rising once again. FOMC minutes on Thursday and June’s labour market report on Friday may provide the next fundamental catalysts.

CRUDE: There was thin trade in crude futures, though Brent (up slightly on geopolitics and continuing supply disruptions) and WTI diverged (technical factors around backwardation). The Iranians have been vocal, with Iran's revolutionary guards reportedly ready to start a policy of preventing oil exports if Iranian oil sales are banned; Iranian President Rouhani said the nation will remain in the nuclear pact without the US, if its benefits are guaranteed; and Iran's OPEC governor says Trump's pressure on international firms to not purchase oil from Iran is 'self-harm' as it pushes up oil prices. WTI, meanwhile, was lower despite a bigger-than-expected crude draw reported by the API on Tuesday. One desk suggested that WTI may see selling pressure given the prominent backwardations in the front-months; the desk noted that it was June 2014 when this degree of backwardation was last observed in WTI, and subsequently, the front month selling off, and periods of contango saw the front contract rally. The rationale seems to be that when the front month goes highly bid (which implies a shortage of supply in the underlying commodity) it encourages fresh supplies to come to the market; nevertheless, the desk noted that the term structure of WTI still implies downside risks.

EUR: The CDU/CSU deal on immigration only provided a fleeting bounce for EURUSD, which is in negative territory (albeit, slight). 1.1635 was support in thin trade, though there were a few downside breaches, and we are consolidating between that level and 1.1650 as we close out the day in Europe. Technicians suggest the topside level to watch is 1.1720-30.

USD: The PBOC fixing the yuan stronger capped USD upside in Asia trade – and yuan strength was also aided by firmer Caixin PMIs – though the buck found strength in late Asia/early European trade, though trading volumes have been thin. The DXY is a touch stronger in generally rangebound action in the European afternoon. Attention is now on tomorrow’s FOMC minutes, Friday’s payrolls report, and of course, lingering concerns on global trade wars – tariffs on USD 34bln of goods coming into effect on 6 July, with China expected to retaliate quickly after.

GBP: Solid PMI data helped Sterling reclaim 1.32 against the buck, though backed-off the weekly high around 1.3225, and cable has been consolidating above the 1.32 handle; the pound briefly breached 0.88 versus the EUR, though is trading above the figure as we close out the session in Europe. Attention will likely fall back on Brexit newsflow towards the back-end of the week, when UK PM May will meet with her Cabinet at Chequers, and decisions will reportedly be taken on the UK’s future partnership with the EU, and the details of the highly anticipated ‘white paper’ also said to be unveiled (expectations are for a very soft version of Brexit, according to reports).

COMMODITY FX: The complex is flat and rangey vs the buck amid quiet AUD: Broad USD strength in the latter part of Asia trading/early European trade resulted in the Aussie paring away gains made after decent retail sales data overnight. The 0.74 handle was given once again.

SEK: The EURSEK sell-off has extended into Wednesday trade, following Tuesday’s hawkish Riksbank, helped along by rising PMI data. Given how far the SEK has come in such a short space of time, some desks are looking to fade rallies near 10.30.

subject: IAG (IAG LN) says June load factor was 87.4% (Prev. 84.3%)
UBS Sales recommends short $EURGBP (entry 0.8850, target 0.87, stop 0.8920)
content: • says political risks in Europe are still elevated (Germany and Italy), BOE turning more hawkish compared to the dovish ECB, CFTC data shows positioning is still net long EUR versus short GBP

subject: German Chancellor Merkel says she expects the coalition to be able to continue working in coming years
Turkey Economy Minister Zeybekci says food inflation is the main reason for above-expected CPI in June; says CBRT would surely take necessary steps
Irish PM Varadkar says a hard Brexit is unlikely, but must prepare; UK-wide customs plan could apply; reiterates that EU's 4 freedoms must apply to any deal
VW, BMW and Daimler heads are set to talk to US policy makers about trade
Iran's OPEC governor says Trump's pressure on international firms to not purchase oil from Iran is 'self harm' as it pushes up oil prices; according to Shana
UAE's Adnoc sets June Murban crude at USD 77.20/bbl Prev. USD 78.25/bbl
MBA Mortgage Applications -0.5% vs. Prev. -4.9%
Iran's revolutionary guards are ready to start a policy of preventing oil exports if Iranian oil sales are banned
Chinese Finance Ministry says they will not implement tariffs before the US does
analysis_details: • This follows earlier reports that China is to implement tariffs on USD 34bln worth of US goods as of midnight Beijing time on July 6th, according to a source

subject: Credit Agricole (ACA FP) is reportedly considering the sale of its Polish unit, as according to sources
Riksbank's Skingsley says she doesn't want to give any preference for raising rates at the October or December meeting
RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Sterling outperforms on a hat-trick of PMIs - 4th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European stocks trade mixed (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%) with IT names taking a hit after Micron shares tumbled almost 7% after losing a patent suit in China, which in turn weighed on other Asian and European chipmakers. Microfocus (-1.9%), Infineon (-1.5%) and STMicroelectronics (-2.6%) are seen at the foot of their respective bourses. European auto names are in the green after reports the EU in considering talks with the leading global auto exporters in efforts to avoid a full-blown trade war. In stocks specifics, Altice (-6.1%) is the worst performer in the Stoxx 600 amid reports the company does not intend to sell their French telecom component SFR.

FX

USD - Another broad downturn in the Dollar after reports of further sales in China to prop up the YUAN, although the PBoC will be less aggressive in terms of intervention than it was in 2015, according to sources, and with leverage names said to be net sellers of the Greenback over July 4. However, the index has bounced off overnight lows below 94.500 in holiday-thinned trading conditions that are exacerbating price moves.

NZD/JPY - Early outperformers, with the Kiwi holding the bulk of its recovery gains vs the Usd and 0.6750+ status, while the Jpy has bounced off 111.00+ lows again as the headline pair seems to be forming multi-peak resistance alongside the EUR cross at 129.50. Moreover, Eur/Usd remains pivotal around its 30 DMA (1.1666) and faces mega option-related offers on top of psychological sellers at the 1.1700 level where a total of 4 bn expiries run off tomorrow and Friday.

GBP - 3 out of 3 (or 4 if you count the knock-out win vs Colombia of course!) in terms of PMI beats for the UK, and a very impressive services headline has helped Cable retest 1.3200, while Eur/Gbp has retreated through 0.8850 yet again. However, the Pound has not been able better its wtd peak vs the Greenback around 1.3225, yet.

AUD/CAD/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, with the Aud unable to sustain momentum above 0.7400 even though retail sales data came in above forecast overnight, as the Nzd cross reverses further from highs just shy of 1.1000 to almost 1.0900. The Loonie remains close to recent highs vs its US counterpart in the 1.3150 area, but off best levels just above 1.3100 in wake of Tuesday’s stronger Canadian manufacturing PMI. The Franc is even more rangebound between 0.9905-30.

SEK/TRY - Starkly contrasting fortunes for the Krona and Lira, with the former getting another lift from hawkish Riksbank rhetoric and a Swedish services PMI beat to extend gains vs the Eur (sub-10.2500), but the latter weakening further vs the Usd (4.7000+) on political jitters over high inflation/CBRT tightening prospects.

FIXED INCOME

A similar pattern of trade to Tuesday panned out for a while, as Bunds and Gilts both forged fresh intraday highs, at 162.87 and 123.45 respectively (+15 and +4 ticks), but then recoiled ahead of chart and recent session peak resistance, with UK bonds (and Short Sterling contracts) also sold on the back of the stellar services PMI. To recap, the headline index not only exceeded forecasts by a big margin, but in doing so also posted a new ytd best, and as the largest sector in overall growth terms could well prompt more BoE neutrals to join the 3 MPC hawks. Hence, Gilts are just off a new Liffe base (123.17) and the STIR strip is up to 3 ticks adrift (-4 ticks at worst), while Bunds have recovered from a knee-jerk/sympathy retreat to 162.58 amidst choppy trade in Italian BTPs following press reports suggesting more Euro exit studies focusing on bond contracts. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are essentially static and fractionally below par for obvious July 4 reasons.

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade relatively mixed with WTI (-0.4%) losing the USD 74/bbl handle in recent trade. Brent (Unch) initially edged higher as the global benchmark continues to be buoyed by looming threats of supply disruptions (with Iranian and Venezuelan sanctions as well as Libya’s 850K stunt in production) on traders’ minds. Last night’s APIs printed a larger than expected inventory drop of 4.5mln barrels. Some traders mentioned the decline in inventories was largely due to the outage at Syncrude Canada’s 360K BPD oil facility. There has been reports that US sour crude sellers have cut offers for Asian buyers as over concerns of a potential fall in demand after China threatened to impose tariffs on US oil.

On the flip side, gold rebounds to one-week highs of USD 1261.10/oz, accelerated by the recovery in the Chinese yuan from 11-month lows. Elsewhere London copper climbed almost 1% as the red metal recovered from 9-month lows amid the second largest Chilean copper mine potentially facing a 24-hour stoppage within two weeks due to a strike.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
Bundesbank's Wuermelling says the ECB must stick to rules when rolling over bond portfolio
content:
Says: 

Reinvestments must be market neutral and not lead to market distortion.
analysis_details: Source reports last week suggested the the ECB are considering buying bonds with longer maturities as of next year in order to keep duration at the same level. The ECB is expected to have approx EUR 160-180bln of bonds to reinvest next year.

Russian Economy Ministry sees USD/RUB averaging 60.8 in 2018 and 63.2 in 2019; sees GDP growth at at 1.9% in 2018 and 1.4% in 2019
content:
• The Economy Ministry expects GDP growth to pick up to 3.1% in 2021
  • Adding, higher oil output by OPEC and non-OPEC won't cause rapid moves in oil prices

subject: HSBC cuts German 10-yr bund yield forecast to 0.40% (Prev. 0.75%) by end-2018; citing growth worries and German political tensions among reasons
analysis_details: • The German 10-yr bund yield currently stands at 0.291%

subject: China to be less interventionist on the CNY than in 2015; according to sources
content:
• China policymakers are seen as more comfortable with a weaker yuan as the economy slows but could step up intervention to fend off a sharp slide
  • Counter-cyclical factors and tighter curbs on fund outflows are seen as likely options

subject: UK debt and STIR futures: softer for choice pre-services PMI
content: Several bearish factors behind the most bearish/defensive tone on Liffe, with external leads negative, albeit marginally, latest Brexit reports suggesting a soft post-EU relationship and the skew around consensus for the upcoming services PMI toward the upside following manufacturing and construction beats. Hence, Gilts are sitting near the bottom of a 123.40-29 band vs yesterday’s 123.41 close amidst low-key July 4 turnover, while the Short Sterling strip is narrowly mixed, but erring towards 1 tick declines on the day. Back to today’s domestic docket and the aforementioned services survey, expectations are for a flat 54.0 headline reading, but one prominent UK bank is forecasting a rise to 54.5.

subject: German Chancellor Merkel says an agreement on refugees will be forged with EU member states
Danske Bank (DANSKE DC) Estonian branch is said to have been used to launder money
UK Environment Minister Gove says UK Cabinet will agree on a united position on post-Brexit customs plan after the meeting on Friday
Sainsbury's (SBRY LN) CEO says ADSA deal is not having a distraction effect on trading
Riksbank's Skingsley says we want to feel on solid ground on inflation, specifically on inflation expectations before rate rises start
content: • Says has not seen anything in housing market that would be a reason not to proceed with policy as planned

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 0.0mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 681.277bln

subject: Riksbank's Deputy Governor Skingsley reiterates that rates will rise by the end of the year (October or December still possible) ; adding that it does not exclude a smaller rate than usual
EU equity movers this morning: Anglo American (AAL LN) +2.7%, Danone (BN FP) +0.8%, Altice (ATC NA) -4.0%, ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) +2.6%, Sainsbury's (SBRY LN) +1.3%, Infineon (IFX GY) -1.6%
Bunds: acknowledging dip in US Treasuries, but not much else
content: A 12 tick markdown right off the Eurex open for the 10 year German benchmark, to 162.60, but no follow-through selling in typically subdued US holiday volumes and consequently a grind higher since to leave prices around the middle of a tight range back up to 162.70, thus far. Bunds may get more impetus from the run of Eurozone services PMIs, but beyond that Wednesday’s agenda looks bleak from a market-moving perspective, so technical levels could come into play with nearest resistance around 162.89 (Monday’s session best) and support circa 162.42.

subject: China to implement tariffs on USD 34bln worth of US goods as of midnight Beijing time on July 6th, as according to a source
content:
• This is following earlier reports that China were to implement these tariffs on US goods, including  agriculture products, automobiles and "aquatic products." This is in retaliation to the US Trade Representative's announcement on Friday that the U.S. would initially impose an additional 25 percent tariff on 818 Chinese imports worth about $34 billion on July 6.
  • NOTE: This is on July 6th 17:00BST

subject: Italy Euro-exit clauses are being considered for some contracts
Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Compass Group (CPG LN) – Group finance director Thomson is to stand down in December. (Newswires)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – The co. has selected LinkedIn to offer an online learning course. (Newswires)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Retail sales (ex. fuel) +0.8% prev. +2.7%, LFL retail sales (ex. fuel) +0.2% in line with Exp., grocery sales +0.5%, convenience sales +3.6% and online sales +7.3%. Agreed a financing package of GBP 3.5bln in relation to proposed combination. (Newswires)

SIG (SHI LN) – FY expectations unchanged, HY group revenues from continuing operations +0.6%, LFL sales in line with prev. (Newswires)

National Express (NEX LN) - Co. has won a EUR 1bln bus contract in Morocco. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) - Co.'s France CEO Weill has refuted rumours that Drahi plans to sell SFR. (Newswires) 

Equinor (EQNR NO) – Co. and Brazil’s Barra have signed an agreement for Equinor to acquire 10% interest in BM-S-8 licence in Brazil’s Santo basin for USD 379mln. Upon closing, Equinor intends to sell down 3.5% to Exxonmobil (XOM) and 3% to Galp (GALP PL). (Newswires)

Peugeot (UG FP) - Co.'s European unit Opel is considering a partial sale of its European R&D centre, valued at approx EUR 500mln. (Le Monde) 

RHEINMETALL (RHM GY) INITIATED WITH A BUY AT SOCGEN

THYSSENKRUPP (TKA GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT UBS

VICAT (VCT FP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT EXANE

JERONIMO MARTINS (JMT PT) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM REDUCE FROM KEPLER CHEVREUX

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks traded lower following a subdued lead from the holiday-shortened US session, where all majors finished in the red and tech underperformed as Micron shares tumbled almost 7% after losing a patent suit in China, which in turn weighed on other chipmakers. As such, ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were negative with Industrials and Financials the laggards in Australia, while a firmer currency weighed on Japanese exporter names including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which had also reported a decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) conformed to the downbeat tone following another consecutive net liquidity drain and although Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs were more encouraging than the recent misses in the factory gauges, the support from the data was only brief. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with mild support seen from the risk averse tone, as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 960bln of JGBs ranging from 1yr-10yr maturities.

FTSE

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – The co. has won USD 420mln contract for AE 3007H engine sustainment services in the US. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) – An overhaul of the co.’s Convent, Louisiana refinery is set to complete in the first week of August, as according to sources. (Newswires)

BP (BP/ LN) – The co. and Conoco Philips have announced a swap deal, where BP will increase its stake in a major North Sea development while Conoco will grow in Alaska. (Newswires)

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – An investigation by the SFO into the co. has been dropped over the Libor fixing scandal. (Times)

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – A director of the co., Lewent, is being sued by the state of Massachusetts for her role in fuelling the opium addiction epidemic. (FT)

Sky (SKY LN) – Crispin Odey of Odey Asset Management has said that the takeover panel for Sky should increase the minimum share price of the co., stating “It’s important [for the panel] to say that if you’ve put up the price you’re willing to pay for Fox by 30 per cent, you should do the same for Sky,”(Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ryanair (RYA LN) – The co. received notice of ~100 pilots’ strike action set to occur on July 12th  in Ireland, with a threat of more to come. (Independent)

Vedanta (VED LN) – Billionaire Agarwal is facing investor resistance over his USD 1bln bid to buy the co. and take it private. (Newswires)

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) – Total US June vehicle sales -9.9% to 29,125. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – The co. has said they would restructure after signing a deal with Tata Steel. (Newswires)

CAC

Eurofins (ERF FP) – The co. has purchased Laboratoire de Bromatologie de l’Ouest, the food testing laboratory in France. (Newswires)

Peugeot (UG FP)/ Renault (RNO FP) – The two co.’s are looking to offer a car share scheme in Paris to replace Autolib, which was recently shed off by local authorities. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DANONE (BN FP) RAISED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

SMI

LafargeHolcim (LHN SW) – The co. bought a ready mix concrete making co. in the US for an undisclosed amount on Monday. (Newswires)

Partners Group (PGHN SW) – The co. has acquired four EU office assets for around EUR 320mln. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

European Auto Names - The EU is considering starting talks with the world’s largest car exporters so as to avoid a trade war, by reducing tariffs to agreed levels for a specified set of products through a plurilateral agreement. This deal would allow countries the freedom to strike their own deals on tariffs without including all members of the WTO. (FT)

US

* SPX -0.5%, NASDAQ COMP  -1.2%, DJI  -0.5%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.4%, Cons Non-Cyclicals:  +0.5%, Energy: +0.6%, Financials: -0.5%, Health Care:   +0.4%, Industrials: -0.3%, Materials: -0.2%, Telecoms: +1.3%, Tech: -1.0%, Utilities: +0.3%.

* Nasdaq futures underperformed after report that the Chinese court ruled in favour of UMC (UMC) in a patent case against Micron (MU), temporarily banning Micron’s chip sales.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 4th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian shares traded lower, led by Chinese markets
  • USD mostly lower; USD/CNY steadies despite weaker fix amid reports Chinese state banks were selling USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include PMIs from Europe and the UK; US markets closed for Independence Day

ASIA

Asia stocks traded lower following a subdued lead from the holiday-shortened US session, where all majors finished in the red and tech underperformed as Micron shares tumbled almost 7% after losing a patent suit in China, which in turn weighed on other chipmakers. As such, ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were negative with Industrials and Financials the laggards in Australia, while a firmer currency weighed on Japanese exporter names including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which had also reported a decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) conformed to the downbeat tone following another consecutive net liquidity drain and although Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs were more encouraging than the recent misses in the factory gauges, the support from the data was only brief. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with mild support seen from the risk averse tone, as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 960bln of JGBs ranging from 1yr-10yr maturities. 

PBoC injected CNY 10bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 80bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6595 (Prev. 6.6497)


Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Jun) 53.9 vs. Exp. 52.7 (Prev. 52.9). 4-month high. (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Jun) 53.0 (Prev. 52.3)


China is reportedly pressuring EU to issue a strong joint statement against US trade policies at upcoming Sino-European Summit in mid-July, although some EU officials are said to be concerned regarding the proposal. (Newswires)

Chinese state banks were said to be selling USD to support the CNY, according to traders. (FT)

UK

Reports on Tuesday suggest that UK PM May's Brexit Plan seems to be for the “softest possible Brexit”, according to an ITV journalist. (ITV)

Key government papers have acknowledged that establishing a customs system post-Brexit could take up to five years. (Sky News)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Jun) Y/Y -0.5% (Prev. -1.1%).  (Newswires)

EU

EU officials are said to be considering discussions with the world's largest car exporters regarding a deal to reduce tariffs and avert a full-blown trade war. (FT)

Germany SPD Leader Nahles said that progress has been made with CDU and CSU regarding proposal to set up migration transit centres at the border, although an agreement has not yet been reached. (Newswires)

ECB’s Praet said there has been substantial progress so far towards a sustained adjustment in inflation, while he is said to be confident the sustained convergence of inflation will continue in the period ahead even after a gradual wind down of new asset purchases. (Newswires)

ECB’s Villeroy said the Euro area must be strengthened and that the ECB still see robust economic growth. (Handelsblatt)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback languished after the prior day’s losses against its major counterparts and with participants away for Independence Day. This kept the DXY stuck near Tuesday’s lows while EUR/USD and GBP/USD extended on gains, in which the latter just about reclaimed the 1.3200 handle. Elsewhere, AUD was underpinned by better than expected retail sales data and CNH also firmed against the greenback, with the currency unfazed despite another weaker reference rate setting by the PBoC, to extend on yesterday’s intervention-spurred rebound.

Australian Retail Sales (May) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%, Rev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(May) 827M vs. Exp. 1,200M (Prev. 977M, Rev. 472M)
Australian Exports (May) M/M 4.0% (Prev. -2.0%)
Australian Imports (May) M/M 3.0% (Prev. 0.0%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were higher overnight in which WTI crude futures have almost fully recovered yesterday’s aggressive drop from resistance at around USD 75/bbl to briefly below USD 73/bbl, with prices also finding solace from a larger than expected drawdown in headline API crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold prices extended on recent gains with the precious metal underpinned by a weaker greenback and due to its safe-haven characteristics, while the strength across the commodities complex also saw copper trade higher but with prices remaining near to YTD lows as upside was capped by the risk-aversion.  

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (29 Jun) -4.50M vs. Exp. -3.50M (Prev. -9.22M). (Newswires)

US

Treasuries were slightly higher on Tuesday and saw moderate bear-steepening with most of the action concentrated in the belly and long end of the curve where yields were lower by c.2bps. 2s5s, 2s10s and 2s30s narrowed by c.3bps but overall action was quiet ahead of the Independence Day holiday on Wednesday.

The US Commerce Department said on Tuesday that it will allow ZTE to temporarily engage in certain business activities as they aim to escape a 7-year export ban. (FT)

subject: MAS reiterates modest and gradual appreciation of SGD to ensure stability
Indian Nikkei Markit Composite PMI (Jun) 53.3 (Prev. 50.4)
Irish PMI Composite (Jun) 58.1 (Prev. 57.7)

As such, ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were negative with Industrials and Financials the laggards in Australia, while a firmer currency weighed on Japanese exporter names including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which had also reported a decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) conformed to the downbeat tone following another consecutive net liquidity drain and although Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs were more encouraging than the recent misses in the factory gauges, the support from the data was only brief. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with mild support seen from the risk averse tone, as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 960bln of JGBs ranging from 1yr-10yr maturities.

subject: China CASS think tank sees 2018 GDP growth at 6.6%
Saudi Aramco plans to alter calculation for pricing long-term crude sales to Asia which is to be based on an average of DME Oman and Platts Dubai prices instead of average Platts Oman/Dubai prices
PRE-MARKET INDIA STOCK NEWS: Fortis Healthcare (FORTIS IS) received 2 bids in final round from IHH Healthcare and from TPG-Manipal
content:
Bharti Airtel (BHARTI IS)
- Co. CEO says they are seeking to transform the Co. into a tech firm. (Newswires)

Cipla (CIPLA IS)
- Co. received US FDA approval for its Emtricitabine capsule. (Newswires)

Fortis Healthcare (FORTIS IS)
- Co. received 2 bids in final round from IHH Healthcare and from TPG-Manipal which is thought to have reduced its offer. (Newswires)

Other News
- Indian Finance Minister Goyal said government is willing to discuss the issue of autonomy and 'lack powers' of the Reserve Bank in regulating state-run banks, after the central bank had previously called for greater authority to regulate state run banks and prevent fraud. (ET)

subject: EU officials are said to be considering discussions with the world's largest car exporters regarding a deal to reduce tariffs and avert a full-blown trade war, according to reports in FT
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia dampened on spillover selling from holiday-shortened US session; despite encouraging Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs
content:
Asia stocks trade mostly lower following a subdued lead from the holiday-shortened US session, where all majors finished in the red and tech underperformed as Micron shares tumbled almost 7% after losing a patent suit in China, which in turn weighed on other chipmakers. As such, ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are negative with Industrials and Financials the laggards in Australia, while a firmer currency weighs on Japanese exporter names including index heavyweight Fast Retailing which also reported a decline in same-store sales. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) conform to the downbeat tone following another consecutive net liquidity drain and although Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMIs were more encouraging than the recent misses in the factory gauges, the support from the data was only brief.

In FX markets, the greenback languishes after the prior day’s losses against its major counterparts and with participants away for Independence Day. This saw the DXY stuck near Tuesday’s lows while EUR/USD and GBP/USD extended on gains, in which the latter just about reclaimed the 1.3200 handle. Elsewhere, AUD is underpinned by better than expected retail sales data and CNH has also firmed against the greenback, with the currency unfazed despite another weaker reference rate by the PBoC, to extend on yesterday’s intervention-spurred rebound.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher with mild support seen from the risk averse tone, as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 960bln of JGBs ranging from 1yr-10yr maturities.

subject: Bank of Thailand minutes state that accommodative monetary policy stance is required

ANZ Bank (ANZ AT) reportedly may face questioning after former Malaysia PM Najib was arrested for corruption and allegedly funneling USD 1bln into his bank account held at Ambank which is partially owned by ANZ Bank
Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Jun) 53.0 (Prev. 52.3)
BoJ board member Harada says further easing would be required if inflation loses momentum
BoJ board member Harada says BoJ bold easing having intended impact and need to continue with current easing to reach price goal
PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: US Commerce Department gives ZTE (763 HK) temporary authorization to resume some of its activities until August 1st
content:
Beijing Capital International Airport (694 HK)
- Co. will acquire parent’s assets for as much as CNY 4.5bln. (Newswires)

Chinese Estate Holdings (127 HK)
- Co. discloses HKD 5.9bln loss related to China Evergrande stake. (Newswires)

CK Hutchison (1 HK)
- Co. is to purchase remaining 50% stake in Wind Tre from co-owner Veon to turn the Italian telco into a fully owned unit. (Nikkei)

Evergrande Real Estate (3333 HK)
- Co. June contract sales CNY 50.1bln vs. Prev. CNY 41.8bln M/M. (Newswires)

ZTE (763 HK)
- US Commerce Department gives Co. temporary authorization to resume some of its activities until August 1st. (Newswires)

Autos
- China plans to increase fuel standards for diesel vehicles from July next year. (Newswires)

Mobile payments
- Alibaba (BABA) and other mobile payment providers in China face losing out on significant interest revenue when the government requires all prepaid funds to be deposited with the central bank rather than private institutions. (Nikkei)

Steel
- China State Council plans to restrict Hebei steel capacity at 200mln tons for 2020. (Newswires)

Other News
- China State Council Financial Stability and Development Committee says the nation is equipped with favourable settings to defeat major financial risks and combat external risks. (Newswires)
- China Embassy in Washington D.C. issued travel advisory to Chinese citizens travelling to the US in which it noted high costs for healthcare and that public security was not good with shooting, robbery and theft said to be frequent. (Newswires)

Data Recap
- Hong Kong Retail Sales Value (May) Y/Y 12.9% vs. Exp. 12.0% (Prev. 12.3%). (Newswires)
- Hong Kong Retail Sales Volume (May) Y/Y 11.6% vs. Exp. 9.8% (Prev. 11.1%). (Newswires)

New Zealand ANZ Commodity Price Index (Jun) M/M -1.0% (Prev. 1.5%)
Australia sells AUD 800mln 2.75% 2029 Bonds avg, yield 2.61%, b/c 3.46

TAIWAN

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) expected to report Q2 oper. profit rose 5.7%Y/Y to KRW 14.9tln, which is a Q/Q decline from the record KRW 15.6tln during Q1

Asia equity markets begin mostly lower following the weak lead from Wall St where tech underperformance led the declines in a holiday-shortened session ahead of Independence Day; ASX 200 (+0.1%); Nikkei 225 (-0.6%), KOSPI (-0.2%)
